The Mesoproterozoic Belt-Purcell Supergroup (BPS) preserves a thickness of 17 km of dominantly siliciclastic rocks deposited between 1470 and 1400 Ma. The total range of Chemical Index of Alteration (CIA) values, corrected for diagenetic K-addition, are 62–88 for argillites and 55–80 for sandstones, with averages of 72 ± 6 and 68 ± 7, respectively. More intense CIA values, in conjunction with low absolute contents of Sr, Ca and Na, and high Rb/Sr ratios (average 4), reflect an intensely weathered provenance in a hot-wet climate with hot-arid intervals resulting in evaporitic sediments. Covariations of CIA-Eu/Eu* and Sr-Eu/Eu* are consistent with a large catchment area including extensive provenance terranes of weathered recycled sedimentary rocks for the most extreme CIA and Eu/Eu* values, with smaller less intensely weathered juvenile terranes represented by lower CIA values. Accordingly, variations of CIA within the BPS stratigraphic sequence may record some combination of shifting catchment terranes and weathering intensity. Stratigraphic trends in CIA within the Appekunny and Grinnell Formations of 80 ± 6 to 66 ± 4 to 79 ± 5 record the variation in this combination with time.
Siliciclastic rocks record a first order trend of CIA values from CIA ∼80–100 in the Mesoarchean, through ∼80–90 in the Neoarchean, and ∼70–85 in the Proterozoic, to ∼72 for global Phanerozoic shales. These values reflect progressive drawdown of greenhouse gases that promote silicate weathering by their sequestration into carbonates and black shales, as preserved in the geologic record. Second order secular peaks in CIA values correlate in time with mantle plumes that emit greenhouse gases, which enhance silicate weathering. Some of the more intense CIA values in the BPS may also stem from release of volcanic gases during magmatism that accompanied rifting of Laurentia during breakup of the Supercontinent Columbia at ∼1.4 Ga. Overall, CIA values are within the range of modern humid-temperate and humidtropical climatic catchment areas drained by large river systems such as the Orinoco, Nile and Amazon rivers.
Proterozoic rivers have been viewed as mostly braided systems due to the lack of influence of rooted vegetation, which resulted in fast channel lateral migration, high run-off rates, and low bank stability. Many large-scale Proterozoic siliciclastic basins have been preserved, formed by river systems up to pancontinental scale. However, their significance as archives of continental weathering intensity remains under-explored. This study suggests that BPS CIA values reflect more aggressive chemical weathering, since Proterozoic rivers had less sediment residence times due to a lack of vegetation cover, and therefore faster transport time than their modern counterparts. To achieve high CIA values in shorter periods of time without vegetation cover, more intense chemical weathering conditions must have been present.

Siliciclastic sediments may record mineralogical, chemical signatures, and proportions of clays to detrital feldspars that collectively monitor weathering intensity in the source area, which in turn reflects paleoclimate (e.g., Nesbitt and Young, 1982, 2004; Sawyer, 1986; Marsh, 1991; Young, 1999, 2004). Feldspar and quartz constitute ∼80% of the modal mineralogical composition of the upper continental crust (Taylor and McLennan, 1985). Hydrolysis of feldspars and ferromagnesian minerals, accompanied by the depletion of mainly alkali- and alkaline-earth metals in the residual bedrock, are the most common features of the weathering process (e.g., Krauskopf, 1982). Based on these principles, the Chemical Index of Alteration (CIA) was formulated by Nesbitt and Young (1982; see Section 3.3).
The CIA varies from 100 in severely weathered residual clays to ∼50 in unweathered rocks (Table 1). When the CIA is calculated for Upper Continental Crust average composition (UCC; Rudnick and Gao, 2003), Post-Archean Australian Shale (PAAS; Taylor and McLennan, 1985), and Global Shale (Nesbitt and Young, 1982; Table 1) the index is 50, 70 and 72, respectively. Peaks in the CIA at 2700–2500 Ma, ∼1900 Ma, and 800–600 Ma, may imply an unusually warm paleoclimate attributed to an increase in atmospheric carbon dioxide and/or methane levels, and other volcanic gases produced by mantle superplume events, inducing an acidic weathering environment and enhanced silicate dissolution (Condie et al., 2000, 2001; Aarnes et al., 2010; Ernst and Bleeker, 2010).
This study attempts to improve constraints on possible secular weathering variations during the Proterozoic. Weathering intensity is addressed specifically for the Mesoproterozoic (1.6–1.1 Ga) using a large database for siliciclastic units of the Belt-Purcell Supergroup from a series of papers by the senior author that addressed provenance and monazite geochronology (e.g., González-Álvarez et al. (2006) and other papers: Ross et al., 1991; Ross and Villenueve, 2003). As well, we use the results from previously reported databases (e.g., Condie et al., 2001), but recalculated for CIA on the basis of post-depositional K-addition, as for the BPS data, which is a widespread diagenetic/metasomatic phenomenon recorded in siliciclastic sequences of many Archean and Proterozoic basins (e.g., Rainbird et al., 1990; Fedo et al., 1995; Cullers and Podkovyrov, 2002; González-Álvarez et al., 2006; González-Álvarez and Kerrich, 2010). This study discusses weather high CIA values relative to the global shale average of 72 can be interpreted in terms of some combination of latitude, and/or plume and spreading centre magmatic systems that developed during rifting of the Supercontinent Columbia coeval with deposition of the BPS (cf., Pesonen et al., 2003; Zhao et al., 2004; Mulugeta et al., 2007; Ernst et al., 2008; Leach et al., 2010). Weathering characteristics of the BPS are also compared with data for other Archean-Proterozoic sedimentary sequences from a number of settings, tectonic and depositional, Phanerozoic geochemical reservoirs, and geochemical sediment signatures of weathering from modern large-scale river systems such as the Amazon River where the catchment and climate are well constrained (e.g., McLennan, 1993; Roddaz et al., 2005; Savenko, 2006; Li and Yang, 2010).

Mobility of REE and HFSE in Types 2 and 3 were attributed to post-depositional basinal brine activity (González-Álvarez and Kerrich, 2010, Fig. 6A).
Notwithstanding mobility of REE and HFSE in Types 2 and 3, the major element-Cs-Rb-Ba patterns of all three types are comparable, such that there was limited mobility of major elements and Sr during diagenesis (Fig. 3). Moreover, argillites and sandstones selected for this study do not show correlations of Eu/Eu* and CIA with ∑ REE content or ∑ LREE/ ∑ HREE ratios for any of the three REE types. Accordingly, it is concluded that brine activity did not influence either Eu/Eu* or CIA values, hence it is reasonable to use all three populations (Type 1, Type 2, and Type 3) for evaluating weathering of the catchment (Fig. 3; Appendix I).
3.4. Chemical Index of Alteration
The Chemical Index of Alteration was formulated by Nesbitt and Young (1982) using a geochemical approach to address paleoclimate. The formula defining CIA is as follows: CIA = [Al2O3/(Al2O3 + CaO* + Na2O + K2O)] × 100, where CaO* is associated with the silicate fraction of the rock {CaO* = mol CaO − [mol CO2 (calcite)] − [(0.5 × mol CO2)(dolomite)] − [(10/3) × mol P2O5 (apatite)]}. The CIA varies from 100 in severely weathered residual clays to ∼50 in unweathered rocks (Table 1). For samples with no analysis of CO2, CaO* corrections follow the method of McLennan (1993).

4. Results
4.1. Mineralogy and sedimentary structures
Argillites have an assemblage of smectite, illite-muscovite and/or chlorite, with quartz, plagioclase, and K-feldspar (Fig. 2a and b). Chlorite and illite are the most abundant matrix minerals (Fig. 2e and f). The sedimentary microstructure of argillites comprises subparallel, laterally continuous lamination, and/or thin centrimetric bedding with cross-lamination, where lamination is defined by the preferred dimensional alignment of phyllosilicates. Sandstones consist of quartz, plagioclase, microcline and chert lithic fragments, with a matrix the same as the argillite mineral assemblage (Fig. 2c and d). Feldspars are pristine in many samples (Fig. 2d). Sandstone sedimentary structures mimic those for argillites but with climbing ripples and larger scale cross lamination and bedding.
González-Álvarez and Kerrich (2010) strongly supported that, mineralogically and compositionally, sandstones are equivalent to argillites variably diluted by quartz (Fig. 2a–b and c–d); accordingly, both argillites and sandstones from this study were used to evaluate CIA.
4.2. Argillites
Normalized to UCC, argillites from all three BPS successions are characterized by: (1) positive anomalies of Cs, Rb, K and Ba; (2) average values for Al and Ti; (3) deep negative Sr, Ca, Na, and P anomalies; and most K/Cs ratios <5700 (Figs. 3 and 6). Average Eu/Eu* is 0.88. Carbonate content, as measured by CO2, ranges from 1.76 wt% to 0.44 wt% with an average of 0.32 wt% and a standard deviation of 0.53 wt%. Most samples presented CO2 under detection limits.

Texturally, these rocks do not display rock fragments that would be expected from a recycling sedimentary rock, mainly in the highenergy sedimentary facies such as sandstones (see Fig. 2). This observation strongly supports that sedimentary units are not the result of sedimentary recycling.
5. Discussion
5.1. Continental crust, sedimentary rocks, CIA and flora
The average upper continental crust is granodioritic in composition (Rudnick and Gao, 2003; McLennan et al., 2006; Rollinson, 2008; Tolstikhin and Kramers, 2008). Ninety percent of the minerals are quartz and feldspar where modal quartz varies from 20% to 65% and feldspars span 80–35% (with >65% plagioclase); <10% minerals, chiefly chlorite, are mafic (this study). Quartz is resistant to dissolution during weathering whereas feldspars easily break down into clay minerals.
Nesbitt and Young (1982) defined CIA based on the higher mobility of K, Na and Ca under weathering conditions, in reference to the most immobile element Al. This alteration index has been widely used in the literature, and its geochemical validity determined in many specific studies (see Section 3.4; Tables 1–6).
According to Veizer and MacKenzie (2003), ∼70% of the continental crust is covered by sedimentary rocks, and ∼90% of sedimentary rocks are cannibalistically recycled to generate more sedimentary rocks. Accordingly, measured values of CIA may be a composite of several such cycles. Notwithstanding this complexity, CIA values of modern river sediments may reflect the climatic determinants of weathering intensity (Section 5.3).
Aggressive chemical weathering in the Precambrian, without the influence of terrestrial flora, has been attributed to some combination of higher temperatures, greater rainfall, and increased concentrations of atmospheric carbon dioxide that accelerates silicate weathering (e.g., Corcoran and Mueller, 2004). .2. Climate factor dynamics and secular variations

5.5. CIA, Eu/Eu*, Sr, and K/Cs systematics
Negative correlations between CIA and Eu/Eu*, and CIA and Sr are found worldwide in different tectonic settings associated with modern deep-sea sediments (Fig. 6A and B). Gao and Wedepohl (1995) interpreted this feature to be the result of progressive weathering, involving hydrolysis of plagioclase and/or K-feldspar to mica and/or kaolinite, and weathering of ferromagnesian silicates such as amphibole to chlorite and/or smectite. They explained the covariation of decreasing Eu/Eu* with increasing CIA values as due to a trend from smaller catchments dominated by juvenile terranes to larger provenance areas having a greater proportion of siliciclastic input from older recycled sediments. Covariation of CIA with Eu/Eu* is coupled with pronounced negative anomalies of CaO, Na2O, and Sr anomalies (as low as 0.02 relative to UCC values but high Rb/Sr ratios relative to UCC). This is consistent with intense chemical weathering of the source terrane(s) (Table 2; Figs. 3 and 6; McLennan, 1993; Gaillardet et al., 1999; Bhat and Ghosh, 2001). Results for Rb/Sr are consistent with deeply weathered cratonic rocks, where Sr is lost to solution from the weathered regolith whereas Rb is retained in the clay fraction (Nesbitt et al., 1980; McLennan et al., 1983).
Argillites and sandstones of the BPS record a trend of decreasing Eu/Eu* and Sr content to more intense values of CIA in keeping with the results of Gao and Wedepohl (1995), endorsing a continent-scale catchment. As well, they record deep anomalies of Mn, Ca and Na relative to UCC (Fig. 3). Large variability of the BPS CIA values from 55 to 86 is interpreted as the result of some composition of different and evolving geomorphologic units and geologic terranes sampled within the catchment, the wide time span of ∼70 Ma for the total thickness of the sequence, and climatic variations (Sections 5.2 and 5.3). For example, the catchment could have included distal ∼1.8 Trans Hudson and Penokean orogenic belt mountain ranges as well as juvenile rocks of the Yavapi accretionary terrane, Paleoproterozoic intracratonic magmatic provinces, and Paleoproterozoic sedimentary sequences in rift-related, intracratonic (Athabasca), and passive margin basins of Laurentia (Davidson, 2008).
Ratios of K/Cs in this database are mostly lower than the UCC average value of 5700, consistent with an intensely weathered source where Cs is preferentially retained over K in the weathering profile (Fig. 6C; see McLennan et al., 1990). Fractionation of K/Cs may also stem from diagenetic introduction of K. There is no robust test for weathering versus diagenetic influence for the measured K/Cs values, or some combination; however, the simplest interpretation given the combination of covariant CIA versus Eu/Eu*, Sr, and K/Cs is in terms of weathering intensity. .6. Archean-Proterozoic climate and geodynamics
As referred to previously, supercontinent assemblage and reak-up has numerous effects on climatic driving factors at the lanetary scale: oceanic currents are modified; wind regimes, and herefore orographic rainfall, change by building of new orogenic elts; variation in sea level influences continental shelves and new ift basins, changing sedimentation and therefore affecting caron dioxide sequestration; and magmatism perturbs atmospheric as composition influencing weathering and bioproductivity (Kerr, 005). In addition to direct inputs of greenhouse gases from mantle agmatism associated with supercontinent dispersal, gas genertion from contact metamorphism of mafic sills in sedimentary asins has been related to climate change (Aarnes et al., 2010).
Five significant age peaks from zircon age spectra of orogenic ranitoids were interpreted as periods of supercontinent assembly: .7 Ga (Kenorland), 1.87 Ga (Nuna or Columbia), 1.0 Ga (Rodinia), .6 Ga (Gondwana) and 0.3 Ga (Pangea), associated with manle superplume events, with corresponding continental dispersing ges at ∼2.4, 2.2–2.1, 1.3–1.2, 0.75–0.65, and <0.2 Ga (Condie and ster, 2010). According to Ernst and coworkers, there are LIPs and lume events in Laurentia at: 2.50–2.45, 2.22–2.17, and 2.12–2.08, nd the Moyie sills in the lower BPS Supergroup intrude at ∼1.5 Ga Ernst, 2007; Ernst and Bleeker, 2010). In addition, mantle plumes generate LIPs, which include xtrusive flows as well as intrusive sills and dyke complexes. Large olumes of greenhouse gases (CH4 and CO2) have been reported o form by contact metamorphism of organic-rich sediments in ureoles around sill intrusions in sedimentary basins (Aarnes et al., 010); the sill-sediment complex in the Lower Belt, at the Sulivan Pb-Zn deposit (Lydon, 2000), exemplifies this mechanism or emission of greenhouse gases. In the BPS, at ∼1470–1400 Ma, CIA spans ∼68–84, and the totalshale thickness percentage is 40%, suggesting that the BPS could have been associated with the same weathering–plume relationship. However, large ranges of CIA values are wide spread within the sedimentary rock record (Tables 4–6). CIA variations of 15–20 units in the same sedimentary sequence are common over sampled thicknesses of ∼1 to ∼15 km representing time spans up to ∼100 Ma (Tables 4–6). Sampling of a sedimentary sequence for CIA at certain times of Earth history is limited to a specific geographic location. As modern rivers show, different climatic areas may display diverse CIA values yielding an average similar to Phanerozoic weathering conditions (Table 2). This complexity, coupled with poor constraints on the geomorphologic units sampled in most of the data sets generated, and the inherited variability of the weathering signatures within the same weathering-fluvial system (Vital and Stattegger, 2000; Roddaz et al., 2005; Singh, 2009), confers uncertainty on the interpretations or links between extant CIA data sets and global tectonic events. At present, the dataset does not suffice for supporting the global plume–supercontinent weathering link for the Mesoproterozoic (Tables 4–6; Section 5.3).
Most paleomagnetic, paleoclimatic and sedimentary data are consistent with deposition of the Belt-Purcell Supergroup sediments at low latitudes between 10◦ and 35◦ (Chandler, 2000; Leach et al., 2010). Specifically, weathering alteration studies, coupled with petrographic observations of feldspars, hematitic clasts and evaporites in the Belt-Purcell rocks, as well as geochemical studies, have indicated a semi-arid to arid climate with intermittent wetter intervals, supported by the presence in the Belt-Purcell sequence of alluvial aprons and flood-plain deposits produced by abundant stream flow and sheet-flow (e.g., Slack and Höy, 2000; Lydon, 2000; Chandler, 2000 and references therein). These hot arid intervals could explain the lowest CIA values reported in this study, as well as the wide CIA variability.
There is direct and inferred evidence for evaporites in the BPS: textural evidence of gypsum clasts formed in evaporative flats, and the presence of hypersaline formation brines which infiltrated the sedimentary sequence and basement rocks, discharging proximal to the seafloor to generate the world class Zn–Pb Sullivan deposit (Lydon, 2000; Fig. 12B in Leach et al., 2010; González-Álvarez and Kerrich, 2010).
5.8. Sediment residence time and weathering intensity

1) Average CIA values for the Belt-Purcell Supergroup vary from 72 ± 6 and 68 ± 7 for argillites and sandstones, respectively, in conjunction with low absolute contents of Sr, Ca and Na, but high Rb/Sr ratios in argillites, collectively that reflect an intensely weathered provenance in a hot-wet climate with hotarid intervals. 2) Covariations of CIA-Eu/Eu* and Sr-Eu/Eu* are consistent with a

(3) Siliciclastic rocks record a first order trend from CIA ∼80 to 100 in the Mesoarchean, to ∼80 to 90 in the Neoarchean, and ∼70 to 85 in the Proterozoic, notwithstanding second order peaks from mantle plume events. To a first approximation the first order trend reflects a drawdown of greenhouse gases that promote silicate weathering by their sequestration into carbonates and black shales, as preserved in the geologic record. (4) These Mesoproterozoic CIA values are within the range of modern humid-temperate and humid tropical climatic areas and large river systems such as the Orinoco, Nile and Amazon rivers. (5) The Appekunny and Grinnell formations display two intense weathering periods equivalent to humid-dry tropical conditions in modern rivers such as the Orinoco, Parana, Mekong and Amazon rivers (∼80 ± 5), separated by a colder/dryer period of arid-temperate climate such as in the Indus river. (6) It is suggested that BPS CIA values reflect more aggressive chemical weathering since Proterozoic rivers had less sediment residence time due to lack of vegetation cover, and therefore faster transport time than modern rivers. To achieve high CIA values in shorter periods of times without vegetation cover, more intense chemical weathering conditions need to be invoked.
Some of the more intense CIA values in the BPS may also stem from release of volcanic gases during magmatism that accompanied rifting of Laurentia during breakup of the Supercontinent Columbia at ∼1.4 Ga. (7) Second order peaks of weathering of the provenance in the BPS may be associated with elevated levels of atmospheric carbon dioxide degassed from the rifting of the supercontinent Columbia. However, this link remains unclear due to the scarcity of data, and lack of space-time resolutions.

abstractText: The Mesoproterozoic Belt-Purcell Supergroup (BPS) preserves a thickness of 17 km of dominantly siliciclastic rocks deposited between 1470 and 1400 Ma. The total range of Chemical Index of Alteration (CIA) values, corrected for diagenetic K-addition, are 62–88 for argillites and 55–80 for sandstones, with averages of 72 ± 6 and 68 ± 7, respectively. More intense CIA values, in conjunction with low absolute contents of Sr, Ca and Na, and high Rb/Sr ratios (average 4), reflect an intensely weathered provenance in a hot-wet climate with hot-arid intervals resulting in evaporitic sediments. Covariations of CIA-Eu/Eu* and Sr-Eu/Eu* are consistent with a large catchment area including extensive provenance terranes of weathered recycled sedimentary rocks for the most extreme CIA and Eu/Eu* values, with smaller less intensely weathered juvenile terranes represented by lower CIA values. Accordingly, variations of CIA within the BPS stratigraphic sequence may record some combination of shifting catchment terranes and weathering intensity. Stratigraphic trends in CIA within the Appekunny and Grinnell Formations of 80 ± 6 to 66 ± 4 to 79 ± 5 record the variation in this combination with time. Siliciclastic rocks record a first order trend of CIA values from CIA ∼80–100 in the Mesoarchean, through ∼80–90 in the Neoarchean, and ∼70–85 in the Proterozoic, to ∼72 for global Phanerozoic shales. These values reflect progressive drawdown of greenhouse gases that promote silicate weathering by their sequestration into carbonates and black shales, as preserved in the geologic record. Second order secular peaks in CIA values correlate in time with mantle plumes that emit greenhouse gases, which enhance silicate weathering. Some of the more intense CIA values in the BPS may also stem from release of volcanic gases during magmatism that accompanied rifting of Laurentia during breakup of the Supercontinent Columbia at ∼1.4 Ga. Overall, CIA values are within the range of modern humid-temperate and humidtropical climatic catchment areas drained by large river systems such as the Orinoco, Nile and Amazon rivers. Proterozoic rivers have been viewed as mostly braided systems due to the lack of influence of rooted vegetation, which resulted in fast channel lateral migration, high run-off rates, and low bank stability. Many large-scale Proterozoic siliciclastic basins have been preserved, formed by river systems up to pancontinental scale. However, their significance as archives of continental weathering intensity remains under-explored. This study suggests that BPS CIA values reflect more aggressive chemical weathering, since Proterozoic rivers had less sediment residence times due to a lack of vegetation cover, and therefore faster transport time than their modern counterparts. To achieve high CIA values in shorter periods of time without vegetation cover, more intense chemical weathering conditions must have been present.
title: Weathering intensity in the Mesoproterozoic and modern large-river systems: A comparative study in the Belt-Purcell Supergroup, Canada and USA
